fields.label_text:
This collection of silver slices, all commissioned over a period of twenty years by Professor Benton Seymour Rabinovitch FRS, is proof of the skill and diversity of contemporary silversmiths.  Each artist craftsman has responded to the familiar functional form of the slice in an individual way, producing an astonishingly diverse range of interpretations.  Each piece becomes an enchanting, decorative work of art. Professor Rabinovitch established a close rapport with each artist, always encouraging a freedom of creative expression.  The response of these silversmiths has been not only to be strikingly imaginative but also to honour him by giving him their best work.

This collection is testimony to the significant contribution that one individual can make to supporting the craft of silversmithing.  After commissioning work from some of the most illustrious names in British and North American silversmithing, Professor Rabinovitch has very generously donated his entire collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, through the American Friends of the V&A.

fields.descriptive_line: Silver, London hallmarks for 1997, mark of Kay Ivanovic

fields.name: The Rabinovitch Collection
fields.venue: Victoria and Albert Museum, The Whiteley Silver Galleries

fields.physical_description: The pierced blade has a fluid scimitar shape reminiscent of later 19th C. American wares. It has a single forward positive cusp and sloped rear edge. It is etched into four layers in a flowing pattern over the whole surface. The highly original, parallel split-ribbons lift rises, turns and transforms into a contoured, tubular, tapering handle that is etched over its whole surface in a complementary pattern. The handle is open at both extremities. The surface of the server is lightly anodized and has a lightly brushed satin finish. It will obviously do as well for cake as for fish, and illustrates well the sometimes artificial and semantic nature of the appellations that are used.

Each piece becomes an enchanting, decorative work of art. Professor Rabinovitch established a close rapport with each artist, always encouraging a freedom of creative expression.  The response of these silversmiths has been not only to be strikingly imaginative but also to honour him by giving him their best work.

After commissioning work from some of the most illustrious names in British and North American silversmithing, Professor Rabinovitch has very generously donated his entire collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, through the American Friends of the V&A. [2005]
fields.marks:
London hallmarks for 1997
 Mark of Kay Ivanovitch
fields.public_access_description: This is one of a few servers with a blade shape that corresponds to a contemporary rendering of the classic scimitar shape. The handle and blade have a rare unity. Here is an object that is returning to a liquid form. The artist has captured and cooled the fluidity of molten metal, transforming it into a cascade of water. The handle swirls with a memory of Art Nouveau, plunging down into the layered depths of the pool below. This is a wonderfully evocative piece, while retaining an acute respect for function, with its graspable handle and generous broad blade.
fields.exhibition_history: The Rabinovitch Collection (Victoria and Albert Museum 19/10/2005-25/01/2007)
fields.bibliography: Benton Seymour Rabinovitch and Helen Clifford, <u>Contemporary Silver, commissioning designing collecting</u>, London, Merrell, pp.56-57. ill. ISBN.1858941040
fields.credit: Given by the American Friends of the V&A through the generosity of Professor B. Seymour Rabinovitch
fields.historical_context_note: Part of a collection of fish slices commissioned by Professor Rabinovitch from contemporary North American and British makers.
